welcome: ^You're a full-time Uber driver with two kids to support, and a $1000 mortgage payment coming due in a week.
^Can you earn enough to pay the bill — and make more than other players?
choose_difficulty: ^Your difficulty level will affect how easy it is to earn $1000.
^Easier difficulty: You live in San Francisco and have good bank credit, so it is cheaper for you to rent a car.
^Harder difficulty: You have a bad credit rating and can't afford to live in San Francisco. Instead, you live two hours away in Sacramento.
day_1_start: ^You start bright and early on a Monday morning. Pretty soon, you get your first ride request, from a “Chris”.
day_1_locate_passenger: ^But when you arrive at the pick-up point, you don't see anyone waiting for a ride. What do you do?

call_chris: ^A man's voice answers the phone. “I'll be right there. Just coming out now,” he says.
chris_arrives: ^A few minutes later, a flustered man with a big backpack comes out of a nearby apartment.
in_car: ^“That's me. Sorry about being late,” he says as he gets in the car.

c: ^ You start driving. Chris checks his phone.
^“Yeah,” Chris replies. “Meeting up with a friend, then we're driving to this amazing place in Marin. Lemme tell ya…”

driving: ^Twenty minutes later, you arrive at his destination.
drop_off: ^“Thanks! Sorry again for making you wait,” he says as he gets out. You mark the ride as complete on the Uber app.

car_choice: ^You're going to be spending a lot of time in your car. What model do you lease?

c: ^The Prius is fuel efficient, getting up to 50 miles per gallon.

b: ^Your good credit rating means it only costs $
^Unfortunately, your poor credit means it costs $

c: ^The Dodge minivan qualifies for UberXL rides, which earn higher fares.

b: ^Your good credit rating means it only costs $
^Unfortunately, your poor credit means it costs $

confirm: ^Rent this car? You will also buy insurance for $

s0: ^To prepare for life as a professional driver, you buy...

c: ^Since you always have to be connected to the Uber app, an unlimited data plan will save you from paying overage charges.
^A phone mount lets you use your phone with one hand while keeping your eyes on the road. And you don't want to run out of batteries.
^In case someone makes a mess in your car
^You are, after all, technically running a business as an independent contractor.
^Having a gym membership gives you a place to shower.

b: ^. You used your credit card so you don't have to pay right away.
^. You put it on your credit card so you don't have to pay right away.

weekday_quest_message: ^MESSAGE FROM UBER: “Uber Quest: Drive 75 trips, make $
^ extra. You have until 4am on Friday”
day_1_sacramento: ^You live in Sacramento, where fares are a third less than in a bigger city like San Francisco. Do you drive 2 hours to work in SF instead?

go_to_sf: ^You keep the app on, and score a ride that takes you all the way into San Francisco.

b: ^You check your phone as you arrive in SF.

day_1_sac_afternoon_in_sf: ^SF is a lot busier than Sacramento. It's pretty stressful driving here.

b: ^After driving for so long, you're starting to get hungry.
^Coming to SF was definitely the right decision. But after driving for so long, you're starting to get hungry.

c: ^ You grab a quick slice of pepperoni.

day_1_sac_evening_in_sf_mount: ^You get back online just in time for the busy evening period.
day_1_sac_night_in_sf: ^It's getting late and you have a two-hour drive to get back home.

go_home: ^It's been a long day, and you don't want to burn out too quickly.
keep_driving: ^You're tired and dirty. You might have been able to drive for longer if you had somewhere to shower in the city, like a gym.
gym: ^You take a shower at the gym. Feeling refreshed, you keep driving for just a while longer.

stay_or_go: ^. At this rate, you're unlikely to make $1000 by the end of the week.

c: ^ There's still time to salvage today, you think.

sac_lunch: ^You like driving in a familiar town, especially since it means you can get lunch at your favourite Tex-Mex restaurant.

c: ^ You head home, in time for dinner.
^ Things should pick up during rush hour and dinner time.
^ By this point, it doesn't really make sense to make the two-hour trip to SF. You stay in Sacramento, regretting that you didn't go earlier.

sac_evening: ^It's getting late, and you don't want to burn out too quickly.

day_1_sf: ^MESSAGE FROM UBER: “Uber Quest: Drive 75 trips, make $
^ extra. You have until 4am on Friday”
^You accept the quest, excited at the prospect of exploring San Francisco while earning some money.
day_1_sf_morning: ^That was a productive morning! You decide to stop for lunch.

c: ^ You enjoy a burrito from Señor Sisig food truck before continuing on.
^ You grab a quick slice of pepperoni before getting back on the road.

day_1_sf_evening_mount: ^You get back online just in time for the busy evening period.
airport_incident: ^You are driving a passenger to the airport when you miss the freeway exit. She gets very angry, saying: “Do I need to drive for you?”

c: ^ But you stew over the remark. Especially when you see she gave you a bad rating.
^ You almost get into a shouting match with the woman as you find your way back to the airport.

low_rating: ^Your rating is getting low. If it falls below 4.6, you might be placed under review.
^Try extra hard to be nice and to drive carefully

c: ^Your emotional labour pays off, but leaves you feeling more tired at the end of the day.
^You spend $20 buying water bottles and mints for your passengers.  You're not really sure if they'll have a big impact.
^It's not like you earn more money with a higher rating anyways.

day_1_sf_keep_going: ^It's getting late, and you don't want to burn out too quickly.
no_phone_mount: ^With no phone mount, you're left fiddling with your phone on your lap. Your passenger notices and complains to Uber about your dangerous driving.

c: ^ You are deactivated for 4 hours. You use that time to buy a phone mount and charging cables for $25

b: ^and make your way to San Francisco

day_1_end: ^It's the end of the first day.
day_2_begin: ^It's Tuesday. Your back aches from having spent the whole day in the car yesterday.
gas_receipt: ^You stop to fill up your tank. Do you get a receipt?

c: ^ You keep it in a folder for your expenses. You also take some time to track your mileage, so you can claim tax deductions later.
^ You don’t have time to keep track of stuff like that.

day_2_midpoint: ^You turn on your Uber app and start driving.
surge: ^As you drop off a passenger in the Financial District in the northeast of San Francisco, you notice there's surge pricing in the Sunset District.
^The 3x fare is attractive, but Sunset is 30 minutes away.

chase_surge: ^Tripling your earnings is just too tempting. You start driving over to the surge zone.
^But the roads are busy and the traffic lights are not on your side tonight. You are three blocks away when the surge ends. You've just wasted half an hour.
no_surge: ^“It'll probably be gone by the time I get there,” you think to yourself.

day_2_evening: ^You get a message from your friend. A group of them are meeting up for her birthday dinner
^and asks if you want to join.

b: ^You deserve a break. You turn off the Uber app and go to dinner with your friends.
^You want to, but it'll take too long to get back to Sacramento. You eat dinner by yourself instead before calling it a day.

keep_working: ^Work is more important. You say you can't make it.

c: ^ You turn off the app for a bit to stop the car and stretch your aching legs, but a wave of exhaustion hits you. You decide to call it a day.

b: ^The two-hour drive back to Sacramento is long and boring.

day_3_start: ^It's Wednesday. You wake up to find the sun bright in the sky, and your phone's clock showing 11:39am. You must've slept clean through your alarm.

c: ^You're feeling less tired after a good night's sleep, and more confident getting behind the wheel.

pebble_start: ^As you drive along the highway, a pebble hits your windshield and leaves a chip.

repair: ^You find a nearby auto shop. They take an hour to fix your windscreen, and charge you $30. You put it on your credit card.
ignore: ^It's just a small chip, and you don't want to spend the time and money repairing a car you leased.

data_plan: ^You get a message from your phone provider: You've exceeded your data limit.
^In retrospect, maybe you should've upgraded to the unlimited data plan.
nice_passenger: ^You pick up a friendly passenger and have a pleasant chat during the ride.

g-0: ^Soon, you get a notification. She gave you a $10 tip, and an ‘Excellent Service’ badge:

c: ^ As you pull up for the next pick up, you find that it's for a long trip to the airport.

b: ^Vacuum your car before calling it a day

c: ^ You make sure the car is clean for tomorrow.

pickup: ^Ask the passenger if you could decline

c: ^ The passenger says she's in a hurry and will miss her flight if she has to wait for another Uber.
^ You drop her off at the airport.
^You don't feel like getting in the queue for a ride back, so you drive back to town by yourself.
^You decide to call it a day and finish the quest tomorrow instead.
^ She shouts at you as you pull away. Fortunately, you quickly get a few short rides.
^ You take her to the airport. You don't feel like getting in the queue for a ride back.
^ You decide to call it a day and finish the quest tomorrow instead.

day_4_quest_completed: ^Since you've already finished the quest and the next one won't start until Friday, do you want to take the day off?

c: ^ You need every penny you can earn.

day_off: ^You spend the day with your family. Your son is glad you made time for him, and you get some much needed rest.
day_4_quest_easy: ^It should be pretty easy to complete the last
day_4_quest_hard: ^Today is the last day to complete enough rides for the bonus.
day_4_quest_impossible: ^There's no way you'll complete enough rides to finish the quest. Do you want to take the day off and start afresh when you get a new quest on Friday?

c: ^ If you can't finish the quest, then it's even more important to earn more fares.

day_4_morning: ^As you head out, you remember that you promised your son to be home by 7pm to help him with his homework.

c: ^ You set off for SF, hoping to get more rides there.
^ You make it home in time to help your son with his homework, as you promised.

b: ^It shouldn't be too hard to complete

c: ^You make it home in time to spend the evening with your son as you promised.

day_5_late_start: ^Friday and Saturday nights are some of the busiest times for rides, but the peak period doesn't start until 10pm.

c: ^ You take a rest and try to nap a bit during the day.

day_5_daytime: ^You decide that it's not worth it to disrupt your normal schedule.

b: ^ You head into San Francisco at your usual hour.

windshield_reminder: ^You check your chipped windshield. You can't tell whether the small crack it has become bigger or not.

leave: ^You decide it's still the same size. It'll be fine.

day_5_afternoon: ^You would normally finish up around now.

b: ^Especially since you you have a two hour drive to get back home.

s: ^It's important to keep to a routine

b: ^You stick with your routine and call it a day.

keep_driving: ^You're getting tired, but decide to push on and try to catch the evening crowd.
gym: ^You take a break to shower and freshen up at the gym before continuing.

day_5_evening_start: ^Feeling refreshed after resting during the day, you get in your car and prepare for a long night on the road.

c: ^ You decide it's not worth it.

c: ^ As the passenger is getting out, she vomits again. Ugh!

day_6_deactivated: ^check your Uber app to find that you're still deactivated. You decide to make the most of your enforced day off.

day_6_slept_in_car: ^You wake up, briefly forgetting that you're in your car in San Francisco.

c: ^ You decide to take the day off.

day_6_work: ^MESSAGE FROM UBER: “The San Francisco Giants are playing at AT&T park today. Earn a boosted 1.5x fare for trips from there, from 5pm-6:30pm today”
pebble_crack: ^You are driving when you hear a splintering sound. The chip in your windshield has cracked across the whole windshield. You have no choice but to get it repaired.

c: ^You put it on your card, regretting that you didn't get it fixed earlier.

day_6_afternoon: ^You hear on the radio that the baseball game has just ended.

c: ^You make your way to the baseball stadium before the game ends. Sure enough, lots of people are requesting rides there.
^ You get lucky with a relatively long ride to Outer Richmond, and earn $30 on a boosted fare.

day_6_evening: ^It sure is busy this Saturday evening.

b: ^You can't wait to go home after two days out driving.

day_7_start: ^ more rides to get the weekend bonus.
no_drop_zone: ^A passenger insists you drop her off at the entrance to the Caltrain station, which is a no-stop zone.

c: ^ You stop nearby and explain why you cannot drop her off at the entrance. She's not convinced.

insist: ^She slams the door as she gets out. You get a bad rating from her but that's better than risking a traffic ticket.

b: ^You drop her off quickly. Luckily, there weren't any cops around.

caught: ^As you drop her off, you see a police car pull up behind you.

c: ^You get a traffic ticket (-$260). You'll have to go pay that later.

door_dent: ^As you finish a ride, the passenger opens the door to get out and hits a lamp post, denting your car door.
^“I'm sorry! But I'm in a hurry,” he says as he rushes off. “Why don't you take up with Uber?”

c: ^ You document everything and report the incident to Uber. Uber begins the claim process, but in the meantime your account is suspended.
^ You decide to get it repaired yourself instead. It takes the mechanics two hours to fix it, and they charge you $100. You put it on your credit card.

reported: ^You spend the rest of the day getting your car fixed and arranging for a different rental car so you can get back on the road next week.
